html.p: What: Similar to timechart and stats, but has the ability to use both axes at once.

ol.li: You actually don't need to use both parameters if you don't want.

html.p: Why: chart does a job that's nearly impossible without it. See the examples!
So What: Usually, but not always, chart is a command used to really alter the structure of data, moving things that weren't an axis into being an axis, and vice versa.
Notes: I always get over and by clauses mixed up, but sometimes that gives me an interesting thing in its own right. Don't be scared to try flipping those two!
We're using data we built earlier by using outputlookup. To build this see outputlookup
While yours may differ slightly, that data for us is:

panel.title: A simple example using our test data.
panel.html: Adding | chart sum(cars) as "Cars Sold This Hour" over salesperson by _time changed it into a two-important-axis chart.

search.query: | inputlookup rdf_cars.csv | eval _time = strftime(_time, "%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S") | chart sum(cars) as "Cars Sold This Hour" over salesperson by _time

panel.title: The same, only flipping the over and by clauses.
panel.html: Adding | chart sum(cars) as "Cars Sold This Hour" over _time by salesperson changed it into a different two-important-axis chart.

search.query: | inputlookup rdf_cars.csv | eval _time = strftime(_time, "%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S") | chart sum(cars) as "Cars Sold This Hour" over _time by salesperson

panel.title: A more "real life example"
panel.html: We're counting how many of each status (200, 404, etc) happened by user. When you run this yourself, try over user by status too.

search.query: index=_internal status=* user=* earliest="-15m@m" latest="@m" | chart count over status by user
